comment.author: 70251312@N00
comment._content: Uncorrupted Democratic Boss of Cook County, Illinois (Chicago), returning at the end of August, 1913, from a four-month trip to South America and Europe, with his wife and daughter and a few political cronies. He was greeted on his arrival (via the Lusitania) at the Cunard docks by a mob of Chicago-area officeholders, who dined with him in his rooms at New York City's Waldorf Astoria hotel. "Chicago Men Here to Greet Sullivan," story in New York Times, August 29, 1913: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9E0CE6DC113CE6... Sullivan Interviewed: New York Times story, August 30, 1913: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9D04E3DC113CE6... A brief story in the New York Times, September 7, 1913, reported that Sullivan's friends were boosting him for a U. S. Senate campaign. [He did run for the Senate in 1914, but was defeated.]: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9803E4D9113BE6...
